Key Arguments: The submission emphasizes the importance of freedom of expression as a fundamental human right protected by international covenants and conventions.
It highlights that any restrictions on freedom of expression must be necessary and proportionate, as outlined in various international legal frameworks.
The submission suggests that the proposed legislation could infringe on these rights by potentially limiting freedom of expression without clear justification.
It references the principle that Australian law presumes Parliament does not intend to limit fundamental rights unless explicitly stated.
Notable Quotes: Everyone shall have the right to hold opinions without interference.
The exercise of the rights provided for in paragraph 2 of this article carries with it special duties and responsibilities.
Parliament is presumed not to have intended to limit fundamental rights, unless it indicates this intention in clear terms.
